skills.name: Basic Athletic Stance
skills.description: The foundation of all skiing. A balanced, athletic stance allows you to move efficiently and respond to terrain changes.
skills.whyItMatters: Your stance affects everything in skiing. A strong athletic stance keeps you balanced, reduces fatigue, and prepares you to handle any situation on the mountain.
milestones: Flex ankles, knees, and hips equally
Feel pressure on the whole foot

videos.title: Perfect Ski Stance
videos.description: Master the athletic stance that forms the foundation of all skiing movements.

videos.title: Balance Basics
videos.description: Understanding fore-aft balance and lateral balance in your stance.

tips.content: Imagine you're about to catch a ball - that athletic ready position is your ski stance.
Your shins should gently press against the front of your boots. If you can wiggle your heels, you're in the right position.
Keep your hands where you can see them in your peripheral vision - about belly button height and slightly forward.

drills.name: Statue Check
drills.description: Stop on flat terrain and check your body position from bottom to top.
steps: Come to a complete stop on gentle terrain
Without moving, scan your body from feet to head
Check: Are your ankles flexed? Knees bent? Hips hinged?
Adjust any areas that feel locked or rigid
Hold this position and memorize how it feels

drills.name: Bounce Test
drills.description: Test your stance flexibility with gentle bouncing movements.
steps: Get into your athletic stance
Gently bounce up and down by flexing all joints
Keep skis flat on the snow
Notice if any joint feels stuck
Repeat until the motion feels smooth and effortless

checklists.title: Pre-Run Stance Check
items: Boots buckled snugly but not painfully tight
Joints flexed and ready to move

warnings: Don't lean back - this is the most common beginner mistake and reduces your control

skills.name: Straight Run & Glide
skills.description: Develop comfort with forward motion and learn to maintain balance while the skis carry you downhill.
skills.whyItMatters: Before you can turn, you need to be comfortable moving on skis. The straight run builds confidence and teaches you how skis behave in motion.
milestones: Glide in a straight line without falling
Control speed by choosing terrain angle
Look ahead, not at your skis

videos.title: First Time Skiing - The Straight Run
videos.description: Your first movements on skis and how to glide with confidence.

tips.content: Start on nearly flat terrain - you need just enough slope to keep moving, not to gain speed.
Look where you want to go, about 10-15 feet ahead. Your body naturally follows your eyes.
Keep skis parallel and about hip-width apart - the same width as your stance.

drills.name: Micro Runs
drills.description: Build confidence with very short straight runs.
steps: Find a gentle slope with a flat runout
Start just 10 feet from the flat section
Glide down and let the flat stop you
Each run, start slightly higher up
Focus on maintaining your stance throughout

warnings: Always make sure your path is clear before starting
Start on beginner terrain only - green circles

skills.name: Wedge Position (Pizza)
skills.description: The wedge or 'pizza' shape creates friction to control speed and forms the basis for your first turns.
skills.whyItMatters: The wedge gives you control over your speed without needing to turn. It's your primary braking tool as a beginner and the foundation for wedge turns.
milestones: Feel the inside edges gripping the snow

videos.title: How to Pizza - Beginner Ski Lesson
videos.description: Master the wedge position for speed control and turning.

tips.content: Push your heels out, not your toes in. This engages the inside edges naturally.
A bigger wedge creates more friction and slows you more. Think 'big pizza' to slow down.
Keep your knees slightly bent and pointing forward, not inward.

drills.name: Wedge Sizing
drills.description: Practice making wedges of different sizes to control speed.
steps: Start gliding in a straight run
Push heels out to create a small wedge
Notice how you slow slightly
Make the wedge bigger - feel more braking
Practice going from big to small wedge smoothly

warnings: Don't cross your ski tips - keep them apart

skills.name: Wedge Turns
skills.description: Your first turns! Use the wedge position to guide your skis left and right while controlling speed.
skills.whyItMatters: Wedge turns let you navigate down any beginner slope, choose your direction, and maintain control. This is where skiing really begins!
milestones: Look in the direction of travel

videos.title: Beginner Wedge Turns
videos.description: Learn to link your first turns and control your direction.

tips.content: To turn left, put more weight on your right ski. To turn right, weight your left ski.
Point your belly button where you want to go - your skis will follow.
Finish each turn across the hill to control speed naturally.

drills.name: Garland Turns
drills.description: Practice the turn movement without changing direction completely.
steps: Traverse across the slope in a wedge
Gently turn toward the fall line
Before pointing straight down, turn back across
Repeat this 'garland' pattern
Practice on both sides

checklists.title: Turn Quality Check
items: Linking at least 5 turns in a row

skills.name: Controlled Stopping
skills.description: Learn reliable methods to stop safely and completely on beginner terrain.
skills.whyItMatters: Being able to stop confidently is essential for safety - both yours and others'. It lets you ski with control and handle unexpected situations.
milestones: Stop on demand at any point

videos.title: How to Stop on Skis
videos.description: Master the wedge stop for reliable speed control.

tips.content: To stop, make a big wedge and turn your skis slightly uphill. The combination stops you quickly.
Press down through your feet as you widen the wedge - this increases edge grip.
Keep your hands forward when stopping - this prevents you from sitting back.

drills.name: Target Stops
drills.description: Practice stopping at specific points on the slope.
steps: Pick a spot 20-30 feet below you
Start gliding toward it
Begin your stop 10 feet before the target
Try to stop exactly on the target
Adjust your starting distance based on results

warnings: Always be able to stop before obstacles or other skiers

skills.name: Wedge Christie
skills.description: The transition from wedge turns to parallel skiing. Start in a wedge, but match your skis parallel in the second half of the turn.
skills.whyItMatters: The wedge christie is the bridge between beginner and intermediate skiing. It teaches you to use parallel skis for smoother, more efficient turns.
milestones: Match skis parallel after the fall line
Smooth transition from wedge to parallel

videos.title: Wedge Christie - From Pizza to Parallel
videos.description: Learn the wedge christie to progress toward parallel turns.

tips.content: Focus on bringing the inside (uphill) ski parallel to the outside ski as you finish the turn.
Let the turn do the work - as you cross the fall line, the inside ski naturally wants to match.

drills.name: Match and Hold
drills.description: Practice the matching movement in isolation.
steps: Make a wedge turn
As you cross the fall line, slide inside ski parallel
Hold the parallel position to finish
Come to a stop
Repeat on both sides

skills.name: Traversing
skills.description: Travel across the slope at an angle, maintaining a consistent height and controlling speed through edge angle.
skills.whyItMatters: Traversing teaches edge control fundamentals and lets you position yourself on the mountain strategically.

videos.title: How to Traverse on Skis
videos.description: Master traversing for edge control and mountain navigation.

tips.content: Keep most of your weight on the downhill ski and roll both knees slightly into the hill.
Your uphill hip and shoulder should be slightly forward - this prevents catching your downhill edge.

drills.name: Line Following
drills.description: Follow an imaginary line across the slope.
steps: Pick a point across the slope at your level
Traverse toward it, staying at constant height
Adjust edge angle if you start gaining or losing height
Stop at your target
Traverse back the other direction

warnings: Watch for uphill traffic when traversing across a slope

skills.name: Sideslipping
skills.description: Control your descent by sliding sideways down the fall line, using edge angle to regulate speed.
skills.whyItMatters: Sideslipping teaches precise edge control and gives you a way to safely descend terrain that might otherwise be too challenging.
milestones: Sideslip straight down the fall line
Start and stop sideslip on demand

videos.title: Sideslipping Technique
videos.description: Master sideslipping for edge control and steep terrain.

tips.content: Keep your skis perpendicular to the fall line. Flatten your edges slightly to slip, increase angle to stop.
Stay stacked over your feet - don't lean into the hill or you'll catch an edge.

drills.name: Elevator Drill
drills.description: Practice starting and stopping your sideslip like an elevator.
steps: Stand across the slope with edges engaged
Slightly flatten your skis to start sliding
Slide 10 feet down
Edge to stop completely
Repeat in controlled 10-foot increments

warnings: Look downhill for obstacles and other skiers before sideslipping

skills.name: Speed Management
skills.description: Control your speed through turn shape and line choice rather than just braking.
skills.whyItMatters: Managing speed through technique rather than braking makes your skiing smoother, less tiring, and more controlled on varied terrain.
milestones: Use turn shape to control speed
Maintain consistent speed on blue runs
Match speed to conditions and traffic

videos.title: Speed Control Through Turn Shape
videos.description: Learn to control speed through turn shape and line.

tips.content: Round turns that finish across the hill slow you down. Quick turns down the fall line speed you up.
If you're going too fast, make bigger, rounder turns that take you more across the slope.

drills.name: Metronome Skiing
drills.description: Practice consistent turn rhythm for steady speed.
steps: Pick a comfortable rhythm (count 1-2-3-turn)
Make turns to this count
Adjust turn size to maintain constant speed
The rhythm should feel sustainable
Practice on different pitch terrain

skills.name: Rhythmic Linked Turns
skills.description: Link turns together in a consistent rhythm, developing flow and efficiency in your skiing.
skills.whyItMatters: Rhythmic skiing is efficient skiing. A steady rhythm helps you maintain control, manage fatigue, and develop muscle memory.

videos.title: Linking Turns Smoothly
videos.description: Develop rhythm and flow in your linked turns.

tips.content: Think of skiing like dancing - find your rhythm and let it carry you down the mountain.
Your pole plant (when you learn it) will help establish and maintain rhythm.

drills.name: Corridor Skiing
drills.description: Practice linking turns within an imaginary corridor.
steps: Imagine a corridor 20 feet wide
Link turns staying within the corridor
Each turn should be similar size
Maintain constant speed
Try narrower corridors as you improve

skills.name: Basic Parallel Turns
skills.description: Make turns with your skis parallel throughout - no more wedge! This is the gateway to advanced skiing.
skills.whyItMatters: Parallel turns are more efficient, faster, and open up steeper terrain. This is what most people picture when they think of 'real' skiing.

videos.title: How to Ski Parallel
videos.description: Master the parallel turn for intermediate skiing.

videos.title: Parallel Skiing Drills
videos.description: Drills and progressions for parallel turns.

tips.content: Parallel skiing is about simultaneous edge change. Both skis roll from one set of edges to the other together.
Think about moving your Center of Mass across your skis to start each turn, not pushing your tails out.
The inside ski should be slightly lighter and leading through the turn.

drills.name: Thousand Steps
drills.description: Practice parallel position by stepping through turns.
steps: Start making medium turns
Take tiny steps with both skis through the turn
Keep skis parallel while stepping
Gradually reduce stepping until skis glide together
Feel how both skis stay aligned

checklists.title: Parallel Turn Checklist
items: Skis parallel through the fall line

skills.name: Hockey Stop
skills.description: A quick, powerful stop using parallel skis - just like hockey players stopping on ice.
skills.whyItMatters: The hockey stop gives you an emergency braking option and demonstrates strong edge control skills needed for advanced skiing.

videos.title: How to Hockey Stop on Skis
videos.description: Master the hockey stop for quick, controlled stops.

tips.content: Turn your skis across the fall line and engage edges sharply. It's one quick movement.
Keep your upper body facing downhill as your skis turn across - this prevents spinning out.
Practice on your strong side first, then work on your weaker side.

drills.name: Progressive Stops
drills.description: Build up to the hockey stop gradually.
steps: Start with slow speed parallel stop
Gradually increase speed each run
Focus on edging both skis simultaneously
Work up to a decisive, quick stop
Practice on both sides

warnings: Always check uphill before practicing hockey stops

skills.name: Introduction to Carving
skills.description: Make pure carved turns where your skis cut through the snow without skidding - leaving two clean lines.
skills.whyItMatters: Carving is the most efficient way to turn. It maximizes the technology built into your skis and provides incredible grip and control.
milestones: Leave two clean tracks in snow
Control carve radius through edge angle

videos.title: Introduction to Carving
videos.description: Learn the fundamentals of carved turns.

tips.content: Carving is about edge angle, not skidding. Tip your skis on edge and let the sidecut do the work.
Your skis bend into an arc when edged and pressured - ride this arc rather than steering.
Start with medium-radius turns. Very short or very long turns are harder to carve cleanly.

drills.name: Railroad Tracks
drills.description: Focus on leaving clean carved tracks in the snow.
steps: Find groomed terrain with good visibility
Make medium turns focusing on edging
Look back at your tracks after each run
Clean tracks = carving, messy tracks = skidding
Adjust technique based on track feedback

warnings: Carving requires more speed than skidded turns - start on terrain you're comfortable with

skills.name: Variable Terrain Skiing
skills.description: Adapt your technique to handle natural terrain features, small bumps, and changing snow conditions.
skills.whyItMatters: Real mountains aren't perfectly groomed everywhere. Variable terrain skills let you ski the whole mountain confidently.
milestones: Handle small bumps without losing balance

videos.title: Skiing Variable Terrain
videos.description: Adapt your technique for real mountain conditions.

tips.content: Keep your legs active like shock absorbers - let them flex and extend to absorb terrain.
In choppy or crud snow, keep your weight slightly more centered and make rounder turns.
Look further ahead on variable terrain - you need more time to plan your line.

drills.name: Absorption Practice
drills.description: Practice absorbing terrain variations with your legs.
steps: Find terrain with small natural bumps
Ski slowly at first
Let your legs compress over bumps
Extend legs into dips
Keep upper body quiet and stable

skills.name: Short Radius Turns
skills.description: Quick, rhythmic turns that give you precise control on steeper terrain and in tight spaces.
skills.whyItMatters: Short turns are essential for steep terrain, narrow trails, and maintaining control when you need to react quickly.

videos.title: Short Turns for Steep Terrain
videos.description: Master short turns for control on steeper slopes.

tips.content: Short turns come from quick leg rotation under a stable upper body.
Your pole plant times each turn - plant and turn, plant and turn.
Keep your feet underneath you - don't let the turn throw you to the outside.

drills.name: Windshield Wipers
drills.description: Practice quick edge to edge movements.
steps: On gentle terrain, pivot skis quickly side to side
Keep upper body quiet
Feel legs rotate independently
Add forward movement gradually
Build up to continuous short turns

skills.name: Advanced Carving
skills.description: High-performance carved turns with extreme edge angles and dynamic pressure management.
skills.whyItMatters: Advanced carving lets you ski at high speeds with complete control, maximizing the performance of modern ski design.
milestones: High edge angles with knee/hip angulation
Clean carves on steep groomed terrain

videos.title: Advanced Carving Technique
videos.description: Take your carving to expert level with advanced techniques.

tips.content: Angulation (tilting the body inward) allows extreme edge angles while keeping balance over your outside ski.
Feel the ski build pressure through the turn and release it to propel into the next turn.
Your inside hand should reach down toward the snow on deep carves - this indicates proper angulation.

drills.name: Inclination Progression
drills.description: Progressively increase edge angles through a series of turns.
steps: Start with moderate carved turns
Each turn, increase edge angle slightly
Focus on angulation, not leaning
Feel how much grip increases
Find your current edge angle limit

warnings: Advanced carving requires speed - ensure the trail is clear

skills.name: Mogul Skiing
skills.description: Navigate mogul fields with rhythm and control, using the bumps rather than fighting them.
skills.whyItMatters: Moguls are the ultimate test of balance, absorption, and quick reflexes. Mastering them opens up challenging terrain.
milestones: Link turns through the mogul field

videos.title: How to Ski Moguls
videos.description: Master mogul technique for bump runs.

tips.content: Absorb by pulling your feet up as you go over the top, extend into the trough.
Turn on top of the mogul where your skis are lightest - this is called 'using the zipper line.'
Look 2-3 bumps ahead, not at the bump you're on. Your legs follow your eyes.

drills.name: Slow-Mo Moguls
drills.description: Practice mogul technique at slow speeds.
steps: Find a mogul field with small bumps
Ski through very slowly, focusing on absorption
Extend legs into troughs, flex over crests
Keep hands forward and stable
Gradually increase speed as technique improves

warnings: Start on small, evenly-spaced moguls before progressing to steeper or larger bumps

skills.name: Steep Terrain
skills.description: Ski confidently on steep slopes using advanced edge control and pressure management.
skills.whyItMatters: Steep terrain demands precision. Conquering steeps gives you access to some of the mountain's most exciting runs.
milestones: Commit to the fall line on steep terrain
Use short turns for speed control
Maintain edge grip on firm steep snow

videos.title: Skiing Steep Terrain
videos.description: Techniques for confidence on steep slopes.

tips.content: Commit forward - leaning back on steeps is dangerous and reduces control.
Make your pole plant downhill and use it to help project your body down the slope.
Round out your turns to maintain speed control - don't let the pitch intimidate you into going straight.

drills.name: Progressive Pitch
drills.description: Gradually work up to steeper terrain.
steps: Perfect your short turns on comfortable blue terrain
Move to gentle black terrain
Focus on completing each turn
Gradually tackle steeper runs
Always stop if you feel loss of control

checklists.title: Steep Terrain Safety
items: Warmed up on easier terrain first

warnings: Always assess steep terrain before committing
Know your limits - there's no shame in choosing an easier route

skills.name: Powder Skiing
skills.description: Float through deep snow with proper technique for one of skiing's greatest experiences.
skills.whyItMatters: Powder skiing is what dreams are made of. Different from groomed technique, powder requires unique skills to truly enjoy.
milestones: Float rather than sink in powder

videos.title: How to Ski Powder
videos.description: Essential techniques for deep snow skiing.

tips.content: In powder, ski with equal weight on both skis - this gives you the most floatation.
Use a bouncing motion to unweight and turn - think of it as rhythmic up-down movement.
Keep your hands forward and visible - this prevents leaning back, which causes you to sink.

drills.name: Groomed Powder Prep
drills.description: Practice powder movements on groomed snow.
steps: On groomed terrain, ski with equal weight both skis
Add a bouncing rhythm to your turns
Focus on extension/flexion through each turn
Build this into automatic movement
Apply to progressively deeper snow

warnings: Deep powder can hide obstacles - ski defensively
Always check avalanche conditions before off-piste skiing

skills.name: Dynamic Short Turns
skills.description: High-performance short turns with explosive edge engagement for any terrain.
skills.whyItMatters: Dynamic short turns give you ultimate control at any speed, on any terrain. It's the pinnacle of all-mountain technique.
milestones: Explosive leg extension to start turns

videos.title: Dynamic Short Turns
videos.description: Master dynamic short turns for expert-level skiing.

tips.content: Think of springing from turn to turn - use the energy of each turn to power the next.
Your upper body should point downhill while your legs swing beneath like a pendulum.
Pole plant aggressively - it's both a timing mechanism and a pivot point.

drills.name: Edge to Edge Jumps
drills.description: Build explosive edge transition power.
steps: On moderate terrain, make short turns
Focus on explosively releasing edges
Spring from one set of edges to the other
Skis may briefly leave the snow
Maintain rhythm and control
